info.description: In Scotland Hills, you compete for majority control over 9 hills by playing cards that represent clans fighting for dominance.
info.similarAwards:
2005 Fairplay À la carte Runner-up. 
2000 International Gamers Awards - General Strategy; Two-players.
1999 Meeples Choice Award Nominee
info.ruleText:
While there are 3 different ways to play this implementation, they all follow the same basic principle and learning one will teach you all. I will explain the Scotland Hills way first and then explain the differences:
In Scotland Hills, two players are vying for control of the land by fighting over the hills. To win the game, you either need to control 3 hills that are directly adjacent to each other, or you need to control any 5 hills at the end of your turn.

On your turn, you play a card from your hand to any of the columns/hills on your side of the board. Check to see if you have won the hill. If you have, drag the token in the middle of the two hills to your side. Keep it aligned with the hill you won as it's important for the end game winning condition. Whether you have or haven't won a hill, you will click the "Draw 1" button to take a card and pass the turn to the next player. 

How to determine if you've won a hill:
You will always have to play at least 3 cards to your side of the hill in order to win it. The cards you play will create a "poker hand" of sorts. The strength ranking of these hands is displayed in the upper left with the strongest combination being at the top (straight flush) and the weakest combination at the bottom (highest sum). If you've played 3 cards to your side of the hill, at the end of your turn, you can assess if you've won the hill. If your opponent has also played 3 cards, this is easy to determine. Simply compare the strength of your two hands and the winner claims the token at the end of their turn (NOTE: if you play a card that allowed your opponent to win the hill, they DO NOT claim the token until the end of THEIR turn.). If you both play the same poker hand, then compare the highest total sum of the cards. If the strength and the sum of the two hands is equal, then the player who played the last card on the hill loses.

You can win a hill (or multiple hills!) even if your opponent has not played at least 3 cards to their side of the hill. If you can prove, using the cards face up on hills, that your hand combination can not be beat by any possible combination that your opponent can create, then the hill is won by you. You cannot show cards in your hand to prove that your opponent can't win, the cards must be face up and visible for all in order to do this. (Example: You have played a red 2,3,4 on your side of the board. A Straight Flush! Your opponent has two 5's on their side of the board. The best combination they could create is a Three of a Kind which will always lose to a Straight Flush. You can claim the token in this hill at the end of your turn.

Once a hill has been claimed, you can never play more cards to it, even if you played less than 3 cards to the hill.

The game is over once a player controls 3 hills that are directly adjacent to each other, or a player controls any 5 hills at the end of their turn.

If you want to play multiple rounds as a series- Decide on how many rounds you will play before starting. The winner of the game will score 5 points and the loser gains as many points as hills they control at the end of the game.


Scotland Hills + Schemes
This variant uses all the same rules as above with the following additional deck of 10 Scheme cards. At the start of the game, you will draw 7 cards from the deck, and after playing a card, you can choose to draw from the Scheme deck instead of the standard number deck. You can only play 1 more Scheme card than your opponent, regardless of how many you may hold in your hand. Example: Your opponent has played 1 Scheme card, you have played 0. Your opponent cannot play any more Scheme cards but you could play 1 on each of your next two turns which would put your played number of Scheme cards at 2, compared to their 1. 
The Scheme cards have the following effects:
  • 1-9 - This card is a wild and can be played in your hill. When you are claiming your hill, you can choose to assign it any value and any suit. There are two of these in the deck but you can only ever have one on your side of the hill. If you draw a second one while your first is still on your side, it must sit in your hand for the rest of the game or until the wild has been removed from your side of the hills.
  • 7 - This card is a 7 in any suit and can be played in your hill. You assign the suit when the hill is claimed. 
  • 123 - This card and can be played in your hill. It is any suit and can be a 1, 2, or 3 when you are claiming a hill. 
  • +# - You can play this card in-between you and your opponents where the hill marker sits as long as it has not been claimed. When this card is present, none of the hand combinations matter for strength. Only the sum of all the cards present will determine who wins the hill. 
  • +1 - You can play this card in-between you and your opponents where the hill marker sits as long as it has not been claimed. For this hill to be claimed, 4 cards must be played. All poker combinations must include all 4 cards to be valid (example: a red 3,4,5 plus a green 7 will only count for Highest Sum). 
  • Draw 3, discard 2 - Draw 3 cards from one or both decks. After drawing, select 2 cards from your hand to return to the bottom of their respective decks. To do this, you will need to drag the deck out of the holder by clicking and holding the number in the upper right of the deck, to move it out of the way. Then drag your discarded card to the holder, then drag the remaining cards back on top them. 
  • Move your card - Choose any card (number or scheme) on one of your hills that have NOT been claimed yet. You can move this card to a different hill on your side of the board that is unclaimed, or you can discard it faceup. 
  • Steal opp card - Choose a number card (not scheme) on your opponents side of the board on an unclaimed hill and move it to one of your unclaimed hills. 
  • Discard opp card - Choose any card (number or scheme) on your opponents side of the board on a hill that has not been claimed yet. Discard this card faceup. 

Scotland Battles
This variant uses all the same rules as above but has a deck of 1-10 in 6 suits instead of 1-9. It also uses a deck of 10 Scheme cards with some small modifications. The simplest is that the wild 1-9 card is now a 1-10 card and the wild 7 is now a wild 8. The more interesting twist is the "Draw 3, Discard 2". In this variant, the 2 cards that you discard are placed face down ON TOP of the respective draw piles, so you have insight into what your opponent or you will draw next.
info.helpText:
Players should click to sit and select which way they want to play Scotland Hills/Battle. 

Summary:
Scotland Hills: You are dealt 6 cards from a deck of 54 cards which are numbered 1-9 in six suits. 
Scotland Hills + Schemes: You are dealt 7 cards from a deck of 54 cards which are numbered 1-9 in six suits. There is also a deck of Scheme cards which are available to draw from.
Scotland Battles: You are dealt 7 cards from a deck of 60 cards which are numbered 1-10 in six suits. There is also a deck of Scheme cards which are available to draw from.

If you want to reset the game for a new round, press the Reset button in the upper right corner.
